title: SaskTel Centre
text:
SaskTel Centre (formerly Credit Union Centre, and originally Saskatchewan Place; informally also known as "Sask Place") is an arena located in the <a href="Agriplace%2C%20Saskatoon">Agriplace Industrial Park</a>, <a href="Saskatoon">Saskatoon</a>, <a href="Saskatchewan">Saskatchewan</a>, Canada. With 15,195 permanent stadium seats, and situated near the city's northern entrance, the facility opened in February 1988 with a <a href="seating%20capacity">seating capacity</a> of around 7,800. It was expanded to 11,330 for the <a href="IIHF%20World%20U20%20Championship">World Junior Hockey Championships</a> in 1990. Additional permanent seating was added in 2008 and 2009. The current capacity is 15,190 for hockey.
It is the home venue of the <a href="Saskatoon%20Blades">Saskatoon Blades</a> of the <a href="Western%20Hockey%20League">Western Hockey League</a>, the <a href="Saskatchewan%20Rattlers">Saskatchewan Rattlers</a> of the <a href="Canadian%20Elite%20Basketball%20League">Canadian Elite Basketball League</a> and the <a href="Saskatchewan%20Rush">Saskatchewan Rush</a> of the <a href="National%20Lacrosse%20League">National Lacrosse League</a>, with the arena being referred to as Co-op Field at SaskTel Centre during Rush games as per a separate sponsorship with <a href="Saskatoon%20Co-op">Saskatoon Co-op</a>.
The <a href="Cremation">ashes</a> of Saskatoon-born <a href="Detroit%20Red%20Wings">Detroit Red Wings</a> player <a href="Gordie%20Howe">Gordie Howe</a>, as well as those of his wife <a href="Colleen%20Howe">Colleen Howe</a>, are buried at the base of a statue of Howe outside SaskTel Centre's main entrance.
History.
SaskPlace was constructed as a replacement for the <a href="Saskatoon%20Arena">Saskatoon Arena</a>, a concrete building constructed in Saskatoon's downtown core in the 1930s, and which was in use until 1988, hosting its final hockey game only a week before SaskPlace opened. Nicknamed "The Barn", the facility had outlived its usefulness some 20 years earlier and had become infamous for leaky roofs and substandard amenities, yet Saskatonians were hesitant to lose the landmark and a number of years passed between the 1970s proposal to replace the structure and the eventual demolition of the Arena and the opening of SaskPlace.
In 1982, <a href="Bill%20Hunter%20%28ice%20hockey%29">Bill Hunter</a>, a local sports promoter, attempted to purchase the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Blues">St. Louis Blues</a> <a href="National%20Hockey%20League">NHL</a> team and bring it to Saskatoon. Part of his plan included building an 18,000-seat arena. Two locations were suggested: the site of a decommissioned power plant downtown, just west of the then-present Saskatoon Arena, and another site east of the city's airport in the <a href="North%20Industrial%2C%20Saskatoon">North Industrial</a> area. Despite Hunter's best efforts, the NHL rejected his offer and Hunter's plans to relocate an NHL team and build a new arena collapsed.
The site eventually chosen for the arena was initially, and still is, unpopular with most Saskatoon residents. Situated in the remote Agri Place industrial park at the north end of the city, accessible only via highways 11 and 16 and Marquis Drive, SaskPlace was accused of being too inconvenient for seniors and people of limited transportation to access, as opposed to the original downtown arena site which was close to most bus routes. The city's original plan was to relocate Saskatoon's exhibition grounds alongside SaskPlace as well, but this proposal was defeated in a civic <a href="Referendum">plebiscite</a> following public protest over access and safety concerns. At the time of construction, there were very few businesses and services located in the immediate area. As of 2016, the surrounding area has expanded, but the lack of fan amenities that most would find in other cities, such as nearby bars and restaurants, remains. A <a href="Motel%206">Motel 6</a> was the first hotel to be built near the arena, in 2004. A second hotel was constructed in the early 2010s.
Plans to build interchanges on the two major access routes into the facility were announced soon after the arena opened. However, these plans never developed, with the city and province instead opting to install a set of traffic lights at Marquis Drive and Highway 16 only 27 years after the arena's opening. Near-sighted planning on behalf of the city at the time of construction has led to traffic severely backing up after large-scale events in recent years.
In the early 2000s, Saunders Avenue, a street leading into the parking lot of Credit Union Centre, was renamed Bill Hunter Avenue in honour of Bill Hunter, who died in 2002. This was considered ironic by many Saskatonians, given Hunter lobbied for the facility to be built in another location near the old Saskatoon Arena. The city then transferred the 'Saunders' name to a new street in the <a href="River%20Landing">River Landing</a> redevelopment area—running through the former site of the Saskatoon Arena.
Expansion.
In 2008–2009, the arena was renovated for the <a href="2010%20World%20Junior%20Ice%20Hockey%20Championships">2010 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships</a>. There were 2,981 seats added to the upper deck at the west end of the arena increasing the capacity of the arena to more than 15,000. The cost of the expansion was pegged at $6.7 million. $2 million was requested as a loan from the city of Saskatoon and $3 million from a provincial grant. Hockey Canada may have also contributed about $500,000. The expansion also includes extra washrooms and concessions. The expansion also included the addition of 14 more corporate box seats, bringing the total to 44 and enlarged and improved player facilities such as dressing rooms, weight rooms, coach`s room, equipment room, player`s lounge and medical room.
At about this time, there was a proposal from Ice Edge Holdings to purchase the <a href="Phoenix%20Coyotes">Phoenix Coyotes</a> and begin playing five of the Coyotes' home games each season at Credit Union Centre beginning in December 2009. The logic behind the move, which parallels the <a href="Bills%20Toronto%20Series">Bills Toronto Series</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a>, was that although Saskatoon was likely too small to support an NHL team of its own, it would easily be able to sell out the Credit Union Centre for one game each month. By May 2011, Ice Edge Holdings had abandoned its plan to purchase the team. Although some members of the Ice Edge group subsequently joined IceArizona, the group that ultimately was successful in purchasing the team, IceArizona did not pursue the earlier proposal to play any home games outside Arizona.
The arena hosted an NHL exhibition game in 2011 when the Edmonton Oilers hosted one of their games there. In 2012, the Winnipeg Jets were scheduled to play an exhibition game, but this was cancelled due to the NHL lockout. They made up for the missed date on September 27, 2013 against the Boston Bruins. The Ottawa Senators and Calgary Flames played on September 16, 2013.
In August 2014, <a href="SaskTel">SaskTel</a> acquired the naming rights to the arena, renaming it SaskTel Centre.
Future.
A 2018 study recommended the construction of a new arena and convention centre in the downtown area to replace SaskTel Centre and <a href="TCU%20Place">TCU Place</a>. Both venues were cited as "quickly approaching their end-of-useful life" and not meeting standards in comparison to venues in equivalent markets, specifically citing the arena's "inadequate space and capacity for large event staging and rigging", and poor location and accessibility.
#BeLikeBruce.
<a href="Bruce%20Gordon%20%28Detective%20Sergeant%29">Bruce Gordon</a> was a forward with the <a href="Saskatoon%20Blades">Saskatoon Blades</a> and <a href="Medicine%20Hat%20Tigers">Medicine Hat Tigers</a>, an active hockey player who became the Saskatoon Blades captain during the beginning of the 1980s. Gordon also coached midget hockey. Before his passing Gordon was honoured with a Bruce Gordon banner in the SaskTel Centre, and players adorned their hockey helmets with #BeLikeBruce stickers. Additionally at the season home opener - featuring the two teams Gordon played for, the Blades and Tigers, the "Cops for Cancer" fundraiser raised money in the name of Gordon towards cancer research.
Major events.
The arena's inaugural event was the Saskatoon Blades' first WHL game at the arena, defeating the <a href="Brandon%20Wheat%20Kings">Brandon Wheat Kings</a> 4–3. <a href="Grant%20Tkachuk">Grant Tkachuk</a> scored the first goal in the arena's history.
The Saskatoon Blades have hosted the <a href="Memorial%20Cup">Memorial Cup</a> twice at SaskTel Centre, first in <a href="1989%20Memorial%20Cup">1989</a> (where they lost in the Final to the <a href="Swift%20Current%20Broncos">Swift Current Broncos</a>), and again in <a href="2013%20Memorial%20Cup">2013</a>. As of 2016, they remain the Blades' only two appearances in the Memorial Cup.
During a <a href="WWE">World Wrestling Federation</a> taping at the arena on October 12, 1992 for a <a href="Coliseum%20Video">Coliseum Video</a> release, <a href="Bret%20Hart">Bret Hart</a> of <a href="Calgary">Calgary</a> (whose father, <a href="Stu%20Hart">Stu</a>, was a Saskatoon native) defeated <a href="Ric%20Flair">Ric Flair</a> to win his first <a href="WWF%20World%20Heavyweight%20Championship">WWF World Heavyweight Championship</a>. In a match taped for "<a href="WWF%20Superstars%20of%20Wrestling">Superstars</a>", Calgary's Bill Jordan was squashed by the debuting <a href="Yokozuna%20%28wrestler%29">Yokozuna</a>, who dethroned Hart the following April at <a href="WrestleMania%20IX">WrestleMania IX</a>.
In February 2019, it was announced that SaskTel Centre would host the <a href="2021%20Canadian%20Olympic%20Curling%20Trials">2021 Canadian Olympic Curling Trials</a>, ahead of the <a href="2022%20Winter%20Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a>.
Concerts.
In June 1988, the area hosted a show by <a href="Tiffany%20Darwish">Tiffany</a>.
In 2005, the arena hosted a gala <a href="Royal%20Command%20Performance">command performance</a> for <a href="Elizabeth%20II%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Queen Elizabeth II</a> and <a href="Prince%20Philip%2C%20Duke%20of%20Edinburgh">Prince Philip</a>, hosted by <a href="Brent%20Butt">Brent Butt</a>, as part of a royal visit to Saskatchewan commemorating the province's centennial.
In 2007, the arena hosted the <a href="2007%20Juno%20Awards">2007 Juno Awards</a>. The Juno Awards were to return to SaskTel Centre in <a href="2020%20Juno%20Awards">2020</a>, but the ceremony was cancelled on March 12 due to concerns surrounding the <a href="2020%20coronavirus%20pandemic%20in%20Saskatchewan">coronavirus pandemic</a>.
In October 2014, the arena hosted a show by <a href="Demi%20Lovato">Demi Lovato</a> of her <a href="Demi%20World%20Tour">Demi World Tour</a>.
From June 9–12, 2016, SaskTel Centre hosted six sold-out performances by <a href="Garth%20Brooks">Garth Brooks</a> and <a href="Trisha%20Yearwood">Trisha Yearwood</a> as part of their <a href="The%20Garth%20Brooks%20World%20Tour%20%282014%E2%80%9317%29">World Tour</a>. The shows broke a record for concert attendance at the arena (set by Brooks in 1996), with the first featuring 15,458 attendees alone. The six shows had an estimated total of 94,655 attendees.
The single-concert record would be exceeded by <a href="Metallica">Metallica</a>'s <a href="WorldWired%20Tour">WorldWired Tour</a> stop at SaskTel Centre in September 2018, attracting 16,874 attendees in one of only two Canadian stops on the tour. The band dedicated their performance of "<a href="Nothing%20Else%20Matters">Nothing Else Matters</a>" to those who had died in the <a href="Humboldt%20Broncos%20bus%20crash">Humboldt Broncos bus crash</a>.
In October 2019, SaskTel Centre hosted a two-night stop on <a href="Elton%20John">Elton John</a>'s <a href="Farewell%20Yellow%20Brick%20Road">Farewell Yellow Brick Road</a> tour.
The arena was announced as a stop on the North American leg of <a href="Celine%20Dion">Celine Dion</a>'s <a href="Courage%20World%20Tour">Courage World Tour</a>, but was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and ultimately cancelled in January 2022.
Gordie Howe Memorial.
A bronze statue of former <a href="Detroit%20Red%20Wings">Detroit Red Wings</a> player and Saskatoon native <a href="Gordie%20Howe">Gordie Howe</a> has been located outside the arena since 2005. The statue was created by Michael Martin but remained in <a href="Eston%2C%20Saskatchewan">Eston, Saskatchewan</a> until 1993, when private donations were used to fund its completion. As city property, Saskatoon's city council rejected a proposal to place the statue outside the arena, as they felt it had no artistic value or "enduring quality." The statue, however, would be purchased by the owners of <a href="Midtown%20Plaza%20%28Saskatoon%29">Midtown Plaza</a>, and installed on a street corner near the mall. The placement was criticized by a "<a href="Saskatoon%20Star-Phoenix">Saskatoon Star-Phoenix</a>" columnist, who felt (as per a survey the paper conducted, and an opinion from Howe himself) that the arena would be a more appropriate location for the statue. In 2005, the Gordie Howe statue was moved outside the arena's main entrance.
Following Howe's death in June 2016, the statue transformed into a memorial site for the player. In September 2016, the cremated ashes of both him and his wife <a href="Colleen%20Howe">Colleen Howe</a> were both buried at the base of the statue.
